title: Henri Manuel
text:
Henri Manuel (24 April 1874, Paris – 11 September 1947, <a href="Neuilly-sur-Seine">Neuilly-sur-Seine</a>) was a <a href="Paris">Parisian</a> <a href="Photography">photographer</a> who served as the official photographer of the French government from 1914 to 1944.
Photography studio.
In 1900, Manuel opened a portrait studio in Paris with his brother Gaston, which specialised in <a href="portrait">portrait</a> photography. Manuel quickly became renowned as a photographer of people from the worlds of <a href="politics">politics</a>, <a href="art">art</a> and <a href="sport">sport</a>s, as well as a photographer of art and <a href="architecture">architecture</a>. Soon his portraits were used by <a href="news">news</a> agencies, and in 1910 Manuel's studio began providing a commercial service to news agencies for photographs known as "l’Agence universelle de reportage Henri Manuel".
The studio became the largest photographic studio in Paris and a leading centre where young aspiring photographers such as <a href="Th%C3%A9r%C3%A8se%20Bonney">Thérèse Bonney</a> might go to work. In 1925, the brothers moved their business to 27 rue du <a href="Faubourg%20Montmartre">Faubourg Montmartre</a>, where they expanded their business into fashion photography for the likes of <a href="Chanel">Chanel</a>, <a href="Jean%20Patou">Patou</a>, <a href="Paul%20Poiret">Poiret</a> and <a href="Jeanne%20Lanvin">Lanvin</a>. By 1941 the studio had produced over a million images, spread between fashion photographs, news agency photographs, personal portraits and other images.
The studio was shut down during the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a>, and most of the <a href="photographic%20plate">photographic plate</a>s were destroyed. Some 500 survived, and ultimately passed into possession of the <a href="M%C3%A9diath%C3%A8que%20de%20l%E2%80%99architecture%20et%20du%20patrimoine">Médiathèque de l’architecture et du patrimoine</a>.
